text: After the death of Joshua, the Israelites asked the Lord, “Who of us is to go up first to fight against the Canaanites?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord answered, “Judah shall go up; I have given the land into their hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Judah then said to the Simeonites their fellow Israelites, “Come up with us into the territory allotted to us, to fight against the Canaanites. We in turn will go with you into yours.” So the Simeonites went with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Judah attacked, the Lord gave the Canaanites and Perizzites into their hands, and they struck down ten thousand men at Bezek.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was there that they found Adoni-Bezek and fought against him, putting to rout the Canaanites and Perizzites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adoni-Bezek fled, but they chased him and caught him, and cut off his thumbs and big toes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Adoni-Bezek said, “Seventy kings with their thumbs and big toes cut off have picked up scraps under my table. Now God has paid me back for what I did to them.” They brought him to Jerusalem, and he died there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Judah attacked Jerusalem also and took it. They put the city to the sword and set it on fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, Judah went down to fight against the Canaanites living in the hill country, the Negev and the western foothills.
speaker: Narrator

text: They advanced against the Canaanites living in Hebron (formerly called Kiriath Arba) and defeated Sheshai, Ahiman and Talmai.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they advanced against the people living in Debir (formerly called Kiriath Sepher).
speaker: Narrator

text: And Caleb said, “I will give my daughter Aksah in marriage to the man who attacks and captures Kiriath Sepher.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Othniel son of Kenaz, Caleb’s younger brother, took it; so Caleb gave his daughter Aksah to him in marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day when she came to Othniel, she urged him to ask her father for a field. When she got off her donkey, Caleb asked her, “What can I do for you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She replied, “Do me a special favor. Since you have given me land in the Negev, give me also springs of water.” So Caleb gave her the upper and lower springs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Moses’ father-in-law, the Kenite, went up from the City of Palms with the people of Judah to live among the inhabitants of the Desert of Judah in the Negev near Arad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of Judah went with the Simeonites their fellow Israelites and attacked the Canaanites living in Zephath, and they totally destroyed the city. Therefore it was called Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah also took Gaza, Ashkelon and Ekron—each city with its territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was with the men of Judah. They took possession of the hill country, but they were unable to drive the people from the plains, because they had chariots fitted with iron.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Moses had promised, Hebron was given to Caleb, who drove from it the three sons of Anak.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Benjamites, however, did not drive out the Jebusites, who were living in Jerusalem; to this day the Jebusites live there with the Benjamites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the tribes of Joseph attacked Bethel, and the Lord was with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they sent men to spy out Bethel (formerly called Luz),
speaker: Narrator

text: the spies saw a man coming out of the city and they said to him, “Show us how to get into the city and we will see that you are treated well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he showed them, and they put the city to the sword but spared the man and his whole family.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then went to the land of the Hittites, where he built a city and called it Luz, which is its name to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Manasseh did not drive out the people of Beth Shan or Taanach or Dor or Ibleam or Megiddo and their surrounding settlements, for the Canaanites were determined to live in that land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Israel became strong, they pressed the Canaanites into forced labor but never drove them out completely.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nor did Ephraim drive out the Canaanites living in Gezer, but the Canaanites continued to live there among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither did Zebulun drive out the Canaanites living in Kitron or Nahalol, so these Canaanites lived among them, but Zebulun did subject them to forced labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nor did Asher drive out those living in Akko or Sidon or Ahlab or Akzib or Helbah or Aphek or Rehob.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Asherites lived among the Canaanite inhabitants of the land because they did not drive them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither did Naphtali drive out those living in Beth Shemesh or Beth Anath; but the Naphtalites too lived among the Canaanite inhabitants of the land, and those living in Beth Shemesh and Beth Anath became forced laborers for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amorites confined the Danites to the hill country, not allowing them to come down into the plain.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Amorites were determined also to hold out in Mount Heres, Aijalon and Shaalbim, but when the power of the tribes of Joseph increased, they too were pressed into forced labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: The boundary of the Amorites was from Scorpion Pass to Sela and beyond.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord went up from Gilgal to Bokim and said, “I brought you up out of Egypt and led you into the land I swore to give to your ancestors. I said, ‘I will never break my covenant with you,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you shall not make a covenant with the people of this land, but you shall break down their altars.’ Yet you have disobeyed me. Why have you done this?
speaker: Narrator

text: And I have also said, ‘I will not drive them out before you; they will become traps for you, and their gods will become snares to you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the angel of the Lord had spoken these things to all the Israelites, the people wept aloud,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they called that place Bokim. There they offered sacrifices to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Joshua had dismissed the Israelites, they went to take possession of the land, each to their own inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people served the Lord throughout the lifetime of Joshua and of the elders who outlived him and who had seen all the great things the Lord had done for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua son of Nun, the servant of the Lord, died at the age of a hundred and ten.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they buried him in the land of his inheritance, at Timnath Heres in the hill country of Ephraim, north of Mount Gaash.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that whole generation had been gathered to their ancestors, another generation grew up who knew neither the Lord nor what he had done for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelites did evil in the eyes of the Lord and served the Baals.
speaker: Narrator

text: They forsook the Lord, the God of their ancestors, who had brought them out of Egypt. They followed and worshiped various gods of the peoples around them. They aroused the Lord’s anger
speaker: Narrator

text: because they forsook him and served Baal and the Ashtoreths.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his anger against Israel the Lord gave them into the hands of raiders who plundered them. He sold them into the hands of their enemies all around, whom they were no longer able to resist.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever Israel went out to fight, the hand of the Lord was against them to defeat them, just as he had sworn to them. They were in great distress.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord raised up judges, who saved them out of the hands of these raiders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet they would not listen to their judges but prostituted themselves to other gods and worshiped them. They quickly turned from the ways of their ancestors, who had been obedient to the Lord’s commands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the Lord raised up a judge for them, he was with the judge and saved them out of the hands of their enemies as long as the judge lived; for the Lord relented because of their groaning under those who oppressed and afflicted them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the judge died, the people returned to ways even more corrupt than those of their ancestors, following other gods and serving and worshiping them. They refused to give up their evil practices and stubborn ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord was very angry with Israel and said, “Because this nation has violated the covenant I ordained for their ancestors and has not listened to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will no longer drive out before them any of the nations Joshua left when he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will use them to test Israel and see whether they will keep the way of the Lord and walk in it as their ancestors did.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had allowed those nations to remain; he did not drive them out at once by giving them into the hands of Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the nations the Lord left to test all those Israelites who had not experienced any of the wars in Canaan
speaker: Narrator

text: (he did this only to teach warfare to the descendants of the Israelites who had not had previous battle experience):
speaker: Narrator

text: the five rulers of the Philistines, all the Canaanites, the Sidonians, and the Hivites living in the Lebanon mountains from Mount Baal Hermon to Lebo Hamath.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were left to test the Israelites to see whether they would obey the Lord’s commands, which he had given their ancestors through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites lived among the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took their daughters in marriage and gave their own daughters to their sons, and served their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did evil in the eyes of the Lord; they forgot the Lord their God and served the Baals and the Asherahs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The anger of the Lord burned against Israel so that he sold them into the hands of Cushan-Rishathaim king of Aram Naharaim, to whom the Israelites were subject for eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they cried out to the Lord, he raised up for them a deliverer, Othniel son of Kenaz, Caleb’s younger brother, who saved them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit of the Lord came on him, so that he became Israel’s judge and went to war. The Lord gave Cushan-Rishathaim king of Aram into the hands of Othniel, who overpowered him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the land had peace for forty years, until Othniel son of Kenaz died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the Israelites did evil in the eyes of the Lord, and because they did this evil the Lord gave Eglon king of Moab power over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Getting the Ammonites and Amalekites to join him, Eglon came and attacked Israel, and they took possession of the City of Palms.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites were subject to Eglon king of Moab for eighteen years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the Israelites cried out to the Lord, and he gave them a deliverer—Ehud, a left-handed man, the son of Gera the Benjamite. The Israelites sent him with tribute to Eglon king of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Ehud had made a double-edged sword about a cubit long, which he strapped to his right thigh under his clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He presented the tribute to Eglon king of Moab, who was a very fat man.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Ehud had presented the tribute, he sent on their way those who had carried it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But on reaching the stone images near Gilgal he himself went back to Eglon and said, “Your Majesty, I have a secret message for you.”
The king said to his attendants, “Leave us!” And they all left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ehud then approached him while he was sitting alone in the upper room of his palace and said, “I have a message from God for you.” As the king rose from his seat,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ehud reached with his left hand, drew the sword from his right thigh and plunged it into the king’s belly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even the handle sank in after the blade, and his bowels discharged. Ehud did not pull the sword out, and the fat closed in over it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ehud went out to the porch; he shut the doors of the upper room behind him and locked them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had gone, the servants came and found the doors of the upper room locked. They said, “He must be relieving himself in the inner room of the palace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They waited to the point of embarrassment, but when he did not open the doors of the room, they took a key and unlocked them. There they saw their lord fallen to the floor, dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they waited, Ehud got away. He passed by the stone images and escaped to Seirah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived there, he blew a trumpet in the hill country of Ephraim, and the Israelites went down with him from the hills, with him leading them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Follow me,” he ordered, “for the Lord has given Moab, your enemy, into your hands.” So they followed him down and took possession of the fords of the Jordan that led to Moab; they allowed no one to cross over.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time they struck down about ten thousand Moabites, all vigorous and strong; not one escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text: That day Moab was made subject to Israel, and the land had peace for eighty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Ehud came Shamgar son of Anath, who struck down six hundred Philistines with an oxgoad. He too saved Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the Israelites did evil in the eyes of the Lord, now that Ehud was dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord sold them into the hands of Jabin king of Canaan, who reigned in Hazor. Sisera, the commander of his army, was based in Harosheth Haggoyim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because he had nine hundred chariots fitted with iron and had cruelly oppressed the Israelites for twenty years, they cried to the Lord for help.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Deborah, a prophet, the wife of Lappidoth, was leading Israel at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: She held court under the Palm of Deborah between Ramah and Bethel in the hill country of Ephraim, and the Israelites went up to her to have their disputes decided.
speaker: Narrator

text: She sent for Barak son of Abinoam from Kedesh in Naphtali and said to him, “The Lord, the God of Israel, commands you: ‘Go, take with you ten thousand men of Naphtali and Zebulun and lead them up to Mount Tabor.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will lead Sisera, the commander of Jabin’s army, with his chariots and his troops to the Kishon River and give him into your hands.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Barak said to her, “If you go with me, I will go; but if you don’t go with me, I won’t go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Certainly I will go with you,” said Deborah. “But because of the course you are taking, the honor will not be yours, for the Lord will deliver Sisera into the hands of a woman.” So Deborah went with Barak to Kedesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: There Barak summoned Zebulun and Naphtali, and ten thousand men went up under his command. Deborah also went up with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Heber the Kenite had left the other Kenites, the descendants of Hobab, Moses’ brother-in-law, and pitched his tent by the great tree in Zaanannim near Kedesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they told Sisera that Barak son of Abinoam had gone up to Mount Tabor,
speaker: Narrator

text: Sisera summoned from Harosheth Haggoyim to the Kishon River all his men and his nine hundred chariots fitted with iron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Deborah said to Barak, “Go! This is the day the Lord has given Sisera into your hands. Has not the Lord gone ahead of you?” So Barak went down Mount Tabor, with ten thousand men following him.
speaker: Narrator

text: At Barak’s advance, the Lord routed Sisera and all his chariots and army by the sword, and Sisera got down from his chariot and fled on foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Barak pursued the chariots and army as far as Harosheth Haggoyim, and all Sisera’s troops fell by the sword; not a man was left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sisera, meanwhile, fled on foot to the tent of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, because there was an alliance between Jabin king of Hazor and the family of Heber the Kenite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jael went out to meet Sisera and said to him, “Come, my lord, come right in. Don’t be afraid.” So he entered her tent, and she covered him with a blanket.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m thirsty,” he said. “Please give me some water.” She opened a skin of milk, gave him a drink, and covered him up.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Stand in the doorway of the tent,” he told her. “If someone comes by and asks you, ‘Is anyone in there?’ say ‘No.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jael, Heber’s wife, picked up a tent peg and a hammer and went quietly to him while he lay fast asleep, exhausted. She drove the peg through his temple into the ground, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then Barak came by in pursuit of Sisera, and Jael went out to meet him. “Come,” she said, “I will show you the man you’re looking for.” So he went in with her, and there lay Sisera with the tent peg through his temple—dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day God subdued Jabin king of Canaan before the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the hand of the Israelites pressed harder and harder against Jabin king of Canaan until they destroyed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day Deborah and Barak son of Abinoam sang this song:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When the princes in Israel take the lead,
    when the people willingly offer themselves—
    praise the Lord!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“When you, Lord, went out from Seir,
    when you marched from the land of Edom,
the earth shook, the heavens poured,
    the clouds poured down water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mountains quaked before the Lord, the One of Sinai,
    before the Lord, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
God chose new leaders
    when war came to the city gates,
but not a shield or spear was seen
    among forty thousand in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My heart is with Israel’s princes,
    with the willing volunteers among the people.
    Praise the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You who ride on white donkeys,
    sitting on your saddle blankets,
    and you who walk along the road,
consider
speaker: Narrator

text:
the voice of the singers at the watering places.
    They recite the victories of the Lord,
    the victories of his villagers in Israel.
“Then the people of the Lord
    went down to the city gates.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Wake up, wake up, Deborah!
    Wake up, wake up, break out in song!
Arise, Barak!
    Take captive your captives, son of Abinoam.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The remnant of the nobles came down;
    the people of the Lord came down to me against the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some came from Ephraim, whose roots were in Amalek;
    Benjamin was with the people who followed you.
From Makir captains came down,
    from Zebulun those who bear a commander’s staff.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The princes of Issachar were with Deborah;
    yes, Issachar was with Barak,
    sent under his command into the valley.
In the districts of Reuben
    there was much searching of heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why did you stay among the sheep pens
    to hear the whistling for the flocks?
In the districts of Reuben
    there was much searching of heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gilead stayed beyond the Jordan.
    And Dan, why did he linger by the ships?
Asher remained on the coast
    and stayed in his coves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people of Zebulun risked their very lives;
    so did Naphtali on the terraced fields.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Kings came, they fought,
    the kings of Canaan fought.
At Taanach, by the waters of Megiddo,
    they took no plunder of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the heavens the stars fought,
    from their courses they fought against Sisera.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The river Kishon swept them away,
    the age-old river, the river Kishon.
    March on, my soul; be strong!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then thundered the horses’ hooves—
    galloping, galloping go his mighty steeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Curse Meroz,’ said the angel of the Lord.
    ‘Curse its people bitterly,
because they did not come to help the Lord,
    to help the Lord against the mighty.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Most blessed of women be Jael,
    the wife of Heber the Kenite,
    most blessed of tent-dwelling women.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked for water, and she gave him milk;
    in a bowl fit for nobles she brought him curdled milk.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her hand reached for the tent peg,
    her right hand for the workman’s hammer.
She struck Sisera, she crushed his head,
    she shattered and pierced his temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At her feet he sank,
    he fell; there he lay.
At her feet he sank, he fell;
    where he sank, there he fell—dead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Through the window peered Sisera’s mother;
    behind the lattice she cried out,
‘Why is his chariot so long in coming?
    Why is the clatter of his chariots delayed?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wisest of her ladies answer her;
    indeed, she keeps saying to herself,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Are they not finding and dividing the spoils:
    a woman or two for each man,
colorful garments as plunder for Sisera,
    colorful garments embroidered,
highly embroidered garments for my neck—
    all this as plunder?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“So may all your enemies perish, Lord!
    But may all who love you be like the sun
    when it rises in its strength.”
Then the land had peace forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did evil in the eyes of the Lord, and for seven years he gave them into the hands of the Midianites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because the power of Midian was so oppressive, the Israelites prepared shelters for themselves in mountain clefts, caves and strongholds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the Israelites planted their crops, the Midianites, Amalekites and other eastern peoples invaded the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: They camped on the land and ruined the crops all the way to Gaza and did not spare a living thing for Israel, neither sheep nor cattle nor donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came up with their livestock and their tents like swarms of locusts. It was impossible to count them or their camels; they invaded the land to ravage it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Midian so impoverished the Israelites that they cried out to the Lord for help.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites cried out to the Lord because of Midian,
speaker: Narrator

text: he sent them a prophet, who said, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: I brought you up out of Egypt, out of the land of slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: I rescued you from the hand of the Egyptians. And I delivered you from the hand of all your oppressors; I drove them out before you and gave you their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to you, ‘I am the Lord your God; do not worship the gods of the Amorites, in whose land you live.’ But you have not listened to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord came and sat down under the oak in Ophrah that belonged to Joash the Abiezrite, where his son Gideon was threshing wheat in a winepress to keep it from the Midianites.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the angel of the Lord appeared to Gideon, he said, “The Lord is with you, mighty warrior.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Pardon me, my lord,” Gideon replied, “but if the Lord is with us, why has all this happened to us? Where are all his wonders that our ancestors told us about when they said, ‘Did not the Lord bring us up out of Egypt?’ But now the Lord has abandoned us and given us into the hand of Midian.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord turned to him and said, “Go in the strength you have and save Israel out of Midian’s hand. Am I not sending you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Pardon me, my lord,” Gideon replied, “but how can I save Israel? My clan is the weakest in Manasseh, and I am the least in my family.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord answered, “I will be with you, and you will strike down all the Midianites, leaving none alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon replied, “If now I have found favor in your eyes, give me a sign that it is really you talking to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Please do not go away until I come back and bring my offering and set it before you.”
And the Lord said, “I will wait until you return.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon went inside, prepared a young goat, and from an ephah of flour he made bread without yeast. Putting the meat in a basket and its broth in a pot, he brought them out and offered them to him under the oak.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of God said to him, “Take the meat and the unleavened bread, place them on this rock, and pour out the broth.” And Gideon did so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord touched the meat and the unleavened bread with the tip of the staff that was in his hand. Fire flared from the rock, consuming the meat and the bread. And the angel of the Lord disappeared.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Gideon realized that it was the angel of the Lord, he exclaimed, “Alas, Sovereign Lord! I have seen the angel of the Lord face to face!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to him, “Peace! Do not be afraid. You are not going to die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gideon built an altar to the Lord there and called it The Lord Is Peace. To this day it stands in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
speaker: Narrator

text: That same night the Lord said to him, “Take the second bull from your father’s herd, the one seven years old. Tear down your father’s altar to Baal and cut down the Asherah pole beside it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then build a proper kind of altar to the Lord your God on the top of this height. Using the wood of the Asherah pole that you cut down, offer the second bull as a burnt offering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gideon took ten of his servants and did as the Lord told him. But because he was afraid of his family and the townspeople, he did it at night rather than in the daytime.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning when the people of the town got up, there was Baal’s altar, demolished, with the Asherah pole beside it cut down and the second bull sacrificed on the newly built altar!
speaker: Narrator

text:
They asked each other, “Who did this?”
When they carefully investigated, they were told, “Gideon son of Joash did it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of the town demanded of Joash, “Bring out your son. He must die, because he has broken down Baal’s altar and cut down the Asherah pole beside it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joash replied to the hostile crowd around him, “Are you going to plead Baal’s cause? Are you trying to save him? Whoever fights for him shall be put to death by morning! If Baal really is a god, he can defend himself when someone breaks down his altar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So because Gideon broke down Baal’s altar, they gave him the name Jerub-Baal that day, saying, “Let Baal contend with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now all the Midianites, Amalekites and other eastern peoples joined forces and crossed over the Jordan and camped in the Valley of Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit of the Lord came on Gideon, and he blew a trumpet, summoning the Abiezrites to follow him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent messengers throughout Manasseh, calling them to arms, and also into Asher, Zebulun and Naphtali, so that they too went up to meet them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon said to God, “If you will save Israel by my hand as you have promised—
speaker: Narrator

text: look, I will place a wool fleece on the threshing floor. If there is dew only on the fleece and all the ground is dry, then I will know that you will save Israel by my hand, as you said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And that is what happened. Gideon rose early the next day; he squeezed the fleece and wrung out the dew—a bowlful of water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon said to God, “Do not be angry with me. Let me make just one more request. Allow me one more test with the fleece, but this time make the fleece dry and let the ground be covered with dew.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That night God did so. Only the fleece was dry; all the ground was covered with dew.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early in the morning, Jerub-Baal (that is, Gideon) and all his men camped at the spring of Harod. The camp of Midian was north of them in the valley near the hill of Moreh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Gideon, “You have too many men. I cannot deliver Midian into their hands, or Israel would boast against me, ‘My own strength has saved me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now announce to the army, ‘Anyone who trembles with fear may turn back and leave Mount Gilead.’” So twenty-two thousand men left, while ten thousand remained.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Gideon, “There are still too many men. Take them down to the water, and I will thin them out for you there. If I say, ‘This one shall go with you,’ he shall go; but if I say, ‘This one shall not go with you,’ he shall not go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gideon took the men down to the water. There the Lord told him, “Separate those who lap the water with their tongues as a dog laps from those who kneel down to drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Three hundred of them drank from cupped hands, lapping like dogs. All the rest got down on their knees to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Gideon, “With the three hundred men that lapped I will save you and give the Midianites into your hands. Let all the others go home.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Gideon sent the rest of the Israelites home but kept the three hundred, who took over the provisions and trumpets of the others.
Now the camp of Midian lay below him in the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: During that night the Lord said to Gideon, “Get up, go down against the camp, because I am going to give it into your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you are afraid to attack, go down to the camp with your servant Purah
speaker: Narrator

text: and listen to what they are saying. Afterward, you will be encouraged to attack the camp.” So he and Purah his servant went down to the outposts of the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Midianites, the Amalekites and all the other eastern peoples had settled in the valley, thick as locusts. Their camels could no more be counted than the sand on the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon arrived just as a man was telling a friend his dream. “I had a dream,” he was saying. “A round loaf of barley bread came tumbling into the Midianite camp. It struck the tent with such force that the tent overturned and collapsed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His friend responded, “This can be nothing other than the sword of Gideon son of Joash, the Israelite. God has given the Midianites and the whole camp into his hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Gideon heard the dream and its interpretation, he bowed down and worshiped. He returned to the camp of Israel and called out, “Get up! The Lord has given the Midianite camp into your hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Dividing the three hundred men into three companies, he placed trumpets and empty jars in the hands of all of them, with torches inside.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Watch me,” he told them. “Follow my lead. When I get to the edge of the camp, do exactly as I do.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I and all who are with me blow our trumpets, then from all around the camp blow yours and shout, ‘For the Lord and for Gideon.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon and the hundred men with him reached the edge of the camp at the beginning of the middle watch, just after they had changed the guard. They blew their trumpets and broke the jars that were in their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: The three companies blew the trumpets and smashed the jars. Grasping the torches in their left hands and holding in their right hands the trumpets they were to blow, they shouted, “A sword for the Lord and for Gideon!”
speaker: Narrator

text: While each man held his position around the camp, all the Midianites ran, crying out as they fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the three hundred trumpets sounded, the Lord caused the men throughout the camp to turn on each other with their swords. The army fled to Beth Shittah toward Zererah as far as the border of Abel Meholah near Tabbath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israelites from Naphtali, Asher and all Manasseh were called out, and they pursued the Midianites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gideon sent messengers throughout the hill country of Ephraim, saying, “Come down against the Midianites and seize the waters of the Jordan ahead of them as far as Beth Barah.”
So all the men of Ephraim were called out and they seized the waters of the Jordan as far as Beth Barah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also captured two of the Midianite leaders, Oreb and Zeeb. They killed Oreb at the rock of Oreb, and Zeeb at the winepress of Zeeb. They pursued the Midianites and brought the heads of Oreb and Zeeb to Gideon, who was by the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Ephraimites asked Gideon, “Why have you treated us like this? Why didn’t you call us when you went to fight Midian?” And they challenged him vigorously.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he answered them, “What have I accomplished compared to you? Aren’t the gleanings of Ephraim’s grapes better than the full grape harvest of Abiezer?
speaker: Narrator

text: God gave Oreb and Zeeb, the Midianite leaders, into your hands. What was I able to do compared to you?” At this, their resentment against him subsided.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon and his three hundred men, exhausted yet keeping up the pursuit, came to the Jordan and crossed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to the men of Sukkoth, “Give my troops some bread; they are worn out, and I am still pursuing Zebah and Zalmunna, the kings of Midian.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the officials of Sukkoth said, “Do you already have the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna in your possession? Why should we give bread to your troops?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon replied, “Just for that, when the Lord has given Zebah and Zalmunna into my hand, I will tear your flesh with desert thorns and briers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: From there he went up to Peniel and made the same request of them, but they answered as the men of Sukkoth had.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to the men of Peniel, “When I return in triumph, I will tear down this tower.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Zebah and Zalmunna were in Karkor with a force of about fifteen thousand men, all that were left of the armies of the eastern peoples; a hundred and twenty thousand swordsmen had fallen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon went up by the route of the nomads east of Nobah and Jogbehah and attacked the unsuspecting army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zebah and Zalmunna, the two kings of Midian, fled, but he pursued them and captured them, routing their entire army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon son of Joash then returned from the battle by the Pass of Heres.
speaker: Narrator

text: He caught a young man of Sukkoth and questioned him, and the young man wrote down for him the names of the seventy-seven officials of Sukkoth, the elders of the town.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon came and said to the men of Sukkoth, “Here are Zebah and Zalmunna, about whom you taunted me by saying, ‘Do you already have the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna in your possession? Why should we give bread to your exhausted men?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: He took the elders of the town and taught the men of Sukkoth a lesson by punishing them with desert thorns and briers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also pulled down the tower of Peniel and killed the men of the town.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he asked Zebah and Zalmunna, “What kind of men did you kill at Tabor?”
“Men like you,” they answered, “each one with the bearing of a prince.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon replied, “Those were my brothers, the sons of my own mother. As surely as the Lord lives, if you had spared their lives, I would not kill you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Turning to Jether, his oldest son, he said, “Kill them!” But Jether did not draw his sword, because he was only a boy and was afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zebah and Zalmunna said, “Come, do it yourself. ‘As is the man, so is his strength.’” So Gideon stepped forward and killed them, and took the ornaments off their camels’ necks.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites said to Gideon, “Rule over us—you, your son and your grandson—because you have saved us from the hand of Midian.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Gideon told them, “I will not rule over you, nor will my son rule over you. The Lord will rule over you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “I do have one request, that each of you give me an earring from your share of the plunder.” (It was the custom of the Ishmaelites to wear gold earrings.)
speaker: Narrator

text: They answered, “We’ll be glad to give them.” So they spread out a garment, and each of them threw a ring from his plunder onto it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The weight of the gold rings he asked for came to seventeen hundred shekels, not counting the ornaments, the pendants and the purple garments worn by the kings of Midian or the chains that were on their camels’ necks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon made the gold into an ephod, which he placed in Ophrah, his town. All Israel prostituted themselves by worshiping it there, and it became a snare to Gideon and his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus Midian was subdued before the Israelites and did not raise its head again. During Gideon’s lifetime, the land had peace forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerub-Baal son of Joash went back home to live.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had seventy sons of his own, for he had many wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: His concubine, who lived in Shechem, also bore him a son, whom he named Abimelek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon son of Joash died at a good old age and was buried in the tomb of his father Joash in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
speaker: Narrator

text: No sooner had Gideon died than the Israelites again prostituted themselves to the Baals. They set up Baal-Berith as their god
speaker: Narrator

text: and did not remember the Lord their God, who had rescued them from the hands of all their enemies on every side.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also failed to show any loyalty to the family of Jerub-Baal (that is, Gideon) in spite of all the good things he had done for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek son of Jerub-Baal went to his mother’s brothers in Shechem and said to them and to all his mother’s clan,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Ask all the citizens of Shechem, ‘Which is better for you: to have all seventy of Jerub-Baal’s sons rule over you, or just one man?’ Remember, I am your flesh and blood.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the brothers repeated all this to the citizens of Shechem, they were inclined to follow Abimelek, for they said, “He is related to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They gave him seventy shekels of silver from the temple of Baal-Berith, and Abimelek used it to hire reckless scoundrels, who became his followers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went to his father’s home in Ophrah and on one stone murdered his seventy brothers, the sons of Jerub-Baal. But Jotham, the youngest son of Jerub-Baal, escaped by hiding.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the citizens of Shechem and Beth Millo gathered beside the great tree at the pillar in Shechem to crown Abimelek king.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jotham was told about this, he climbed up on the top of Mount Gerizim and shouted to them, “Listen to me, citizens of Shechem, so that God may listen to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day the trees went out to anoint a king for themselves. They said to the olive tree, ‘Be our king.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the olive tree answered, ‘Should I give up my oil, by which both gods and humans are honored, to hold sway over the trees?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Next, the trees said to the fig tree, ‘Come and be our king.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the fig tree replied, ‘Should I give up my fruit, so good and sweet, to hold sway over the trees?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the trees said to the vine, ‘Come and be our king.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the vine answered, ‘Should I give up my wine, which cheers both gods and humans, to hold sway over the trees?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Finally all the trees said to the thornbush, ‘Come and be our king.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The thornbush said to the trees, ‘If you really want to anoint me king over you, come and take refuge in my shade; but if not, then let fire come out of the thornbush and consume the cedars of Lebanon!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Have you acted honorably and in good faith by making Abimelek king? Have you been fair to Jerub-Baal and his family? Have you treated him as he deserves?
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that my father fought for you and risked his life to rescue you from the hand of Midian.
speaker: Narrator

text: But today you have revolted against my father’s family. You have murdered his seventy sons on a single stone and have made Abimelek, the son of his female slave, king over the citizens of Shechem because he is related to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So have you acted honorably and in good faith toward Jerub-Baal and his family today? If you have, may Abimelek be your joy, and may you be his, too!
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you have not, let fire come out from Abimelek and consume you, the citizens of Shechem and Beth Millo, and let fire come out from you, the citizens of Shechem and Beth Millo, and consume Abimelek!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jotham fled, escaping to Beer, and he lived there because he was afraid of his brother Abimelek.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Abimelek had governed Israel three years,
speaker: Narrator

text: God stirred up animosity between Abimelek and the citizens of Shechem so that they acted treacherously against Abimelek.
speaker: Narrator

text: God did this in order that the crime against Jerub-Baal’s seventy sons, the shedding of their blood, might be avenged on their brother Abimelek and on the citizens of Shechem, who had helped him murder his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: In opposition to him these citizens of Shechem set men on the hilltops to ambush and rob everyone who passed by, and this was reported to Abimelek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Gaal son of Ebed moved with his clan into Shechem, and its citizens put their confidence in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had gone out into the fields and gathered the grapes and trodden them, they held a festival in the temple of their god. While they were eating and drinking, they cursed Abimelek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gaal son of Ebed said, “Who is Abimelek, and why should we Shechemites be subject to him? Isn’t he Jerub-Baal’s son, and isn’t Zebul his deputy? Serve the family of Hamor, Shechem’s father! Why should we serve Abimelek?
speaker: Narrator

text: If only this people were under my command! Then I would get rid of him. I would say to Abimelek, ‘Call out your whole army!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Zebul the governor of the city heard what Gaal son of Ebed said, he was very angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Under cover he sent messengers to Abimelek, saying, “Gaal son of Ebed and his clan have come to Shechem and are stirring up the city against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, during the night you and your men should come and lie in wait in the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning at sunrise, advance against the city. When Gaal and his men come out against you, seize the opportunity to attack them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelek and all his troops set out by night and took up concealed positions near Shechem in four companies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Gaal son of Ebed had gone out and was standing at the entrance of the city gate just as Abimelek and his troops came out from their hiding place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Gaal saw them, he said to Zebul, “Look, people are coming down from the tops of the mountains!”
Zebul replied, “You mistake the shadows of the mountains for men.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Gaal spoke up again: “Look, people are coming down from the central hill, and a company is coming from the direction of the diviners’ tree.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zebul said to him, “Where is your big talk now, you who said, ‘Who is Abimelek that we should be subject to him?’ Aren’t these the men you ridiculed? Go out and fight them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gaal led out the citizens of Shechem and fought Abimelek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek chased him all the way to the entrance of the gate, and many were killed as they fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelek stayed in Arumah, and Zebul drove Gaal and his clan out of Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day the people of Shechem went out to the fields, and this was reported to Abimelek.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took his men, divided them into three companies and set an ambush in the fields. When he saw the people coming out of the city, he rose to attack them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek and the companies with him rushed forward to a position at the entrance of the city gate. Then two companies attacked those in the fields and struck them down.
speaker: Narrator

text: All that day Abimelek pressed his attack against the city until he had captured it and killed its people. Then he destroyed the city and scattered salt over it.
speaker: Narrator

text: On hearing this, the citizens in the tower of Shechem went into the stronghold of the temple of El-Berith.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abimelek heard that they had assembled there,
speaker: Narrator

text: he and all his men went up Mount Zalmon. He took an ax and cut off some branches, which he lifted to his shoulders. He ordered the men with him, “Quick! Do what you have seen me do!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the men cut branches and followed Abimelek. They piled them against the stronghold and set it on fire with the people still inside. So all the people in the tower of Shechem, about a thousand men and women, also died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next Abimelek went to Thebez and besieged it and captured it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Inside the city, however, was a strong tower, to which all the men and women—all the people of the city—had fled. They had locked themselves in and climbed up on the tower roof.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek went to the tower and attacked it. But as he approached the entrance to the tower to set it on fire,
speaker: Narrator

text: a woman dropped an upper millstone on his head and cracked his skull.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hurriedly he called to his armor-bearer, “Draw your sword and kill me, so that they can’t say, ‘A woman killed him.’” So his servant ran him through, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites saw that Abimelek was dead, they went home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus God repaid the wickedness that Abimelek had done to his father by murdering his seventy brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: God also made the people of Shechem pay for all their wickedness. The curse of Jotham son of Jerub-Baal came on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the time of Abimelek, a man of Issachar named Tola son of Puah, the son of Dodo, rose to save Israel. He lived in Shamir, in the hill country of Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text: He led Israel twenty-three years; then he died, and was buried in Shamir.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was followed by Jair of Gilead, who led Israel twenty-two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had thirty sons, who rode thirty donkeys. They controlled thirty towns in Gilead, which to this day are called Havvoth Jair.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jair died, he was buried in Kamon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the Israelites did evil in the eyes of the Lord. They served the Baals and the Ashtoreths, and the gods of Aram, the gods of Sidon, the gods of Moab, the gods of the Ammonites and the gods of the Philistines. And because the Israelites forsook the Lord and no longer served him,
speaker: Narrator

text: he became angry with them. He sold them into the hands of the Philistines and the Ammonites,
speaker: Narrator

text: who that year shattered and crushed them. For eighteen years they oppressed all the Israelites on the east side of the Jordan in Gilead, the land of the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonites also crossed the Jordan to fight against Judah, Benjamin and Ephraim; Israel was in great distress.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelites cried out to the Lord, “We have sinned against you, forsaking our God and serving the Baals.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord replied, “When the Egyptians, the Amorites, the Ammonites, the Philistines,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Sidonians, the Amalekites and the Maonites oppressed you and you cried to me for help, did I not save you from their hands?
speaker: Narrator

text: But you have forsaken me and served other gods, so I will no longer save you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and cry out to the gods you have chosen. Let them save you when you are in trouble!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Israelites said to the Lord, “We have sinned. Do with us whatever you think best, but please rescue us now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they got rid of the foreign gods among them and served the Lord. And he could bear Israel’s misery no longer.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ammonites were called to arms and camped in Gilead, the Israelites assembled and camped at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders of the people of Gilead said to each other, “Whoever will take the lead in attacking the Ammonites will be head over all who live in Gilead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah the Gileadite was a mighty warrior. His father was Gilead; his mother was a prostitute.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gilead’s wife also bore him sons, and when they were grown up, they drove Jephthah away. “You are not going to get any inheritance in our family,” they said, “because you are the son of another woman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jephthah fled from his brothers and settled in the land of Tob, where a gang of scoundrels gathered around him and followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, when the Ammonites were fighting against Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: the elders of Gilead went to get Jephthah from the land of Tob.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Come,” they said, “be our commander, so we can fight the Ammonites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah said to them, “Didn’t you hate me and drive me from my father’s house? Why do you come to me now, when you’re in trouble?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of Gilead said to him, “Nevertheless, we are turning to you now; come with us to fight the Ammonites, and you will be head over all of us who live in Gilead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah answered, “Suppose you take me back to fight the Ammonites and the Lord gives them to me—will I really be your head?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of Gilead replied, “The Lord is our witness; we will certainly do as you say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jephthah went with the elders of Gilead, and the people made him head and commander over them. And he repeated all his words before the Lord in Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jephthah sent messengers to the Ammonite king with the question: “What do you have against me that you have attacked my country?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of the Ammonites answered Jephthah’s messengers, “When Israel came up out of Egypt, they took away my land from the Arnon to the Jabbok, all the way to the Jordan. Now give it back peaceably.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah sent back messengers to the Ammonite king,
speaker: Narrator

text:
saying:
“This is what Jephthah says: Israel did not take the land of Moab or the land of the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they came up out of Egypt, Israel went through the wilderness to the Red Sea and on to Kadesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel sent messengers to the king of Edom, saying, ‘Give us permission to go through your country,’ but the king of Edom would not listen. They sent also to the king of Moab, and he refused. So Israel stayed at Kadesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Next they traveled through the wilderness, skirted the lands of Edom and Moab, passed along the eastern side of the country of Moab, and camped on the other side of the Arnon. They did not enter the territory of Moab, for the Arnon was its border.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then Israel sent messengers to Sihon king of the Amorites, who ruled in Heshbon, and said to him, ‘Let us pass through your country to our own place.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Sihon, however, did not trust Israel to pass through his territory. He mustered all his troops and encamped at Jahaz and fought with Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Lord, the God of Israel, gave Sihon and his whole army into Israel’s hands, and they defeated them. Israel took over all the land of the Amorites who lived in that country,
speaker: Narrator

text: capturing all of it from the Arnon to the Jabbok and from the desert to the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now since the Lord, the God of Israel, has driven the Amorites out before his people Israel, what right have you to take it over?
speaker: Narrator

text: Will you not take what your god Chemosh gives you? Likewise, whatever the Lord our God has given us, we will possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: Are you any better than Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab? Did he ever quarrel with Israel or fight with them?
speaker: Narrator

text: For three hundred years Israel occupied Heshbon, Aroer, the surrounding settlements and all the towns along the Arnon. Why didn’t you retake them during that time?
speaker: Narrator

text: I have not wronged you, but you are doing me wrong by waging war against me. Let the Lord, the Judge, decide the dispute this day between the Israelites and the Ammonites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Ammon, however, paid no attention to the message Jephthah sent him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit of the Lord came on Jephthah. He crossed Gilead and Manasseh, passed through Mizpah of Gilead, and from there he advanced against the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jephthah made a vow to the Lord: “If you give the Ammonites into my hands,
speaker: Narrator

text: whatever comes out of the door of my house to meet me when I return in triumph from the Ammonites will be the Lord’s, and I will sacrifice it as a burnt offering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jephthah went over to fight the Ammonites, and the Lord gave them into his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: He devastated twenty towns from Aroer to the vicinity of Minnith, as far as Abel Keramim. Thus Israel subdued Ammon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jephthah returned to his home in Mizpah, who should come out to meet him but his daughter, dancing to the sound of timbrels! She was an only child. Except for her he had neither son nor daughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he saw her, he tore his clothes and cried, “Oh no, my daughter! You have brought me down and I am devastated. I have made a vow to the Lord that I cannot break.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “My father,” she replied, “you have given your word to the Lord. Do to me just as you promised, now that the Lord has avenged you of your enemies, the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: But grant me this one request,” she said. “Give me two months to roam the hills and weep with my friends, because I will never marry.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may go,” he said. And he let her go for two months. She and her friends went into the hills and wept because she would never marry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After the two months, she returned to her father, and he did to her as he had vowed. And she was a virgin.
From this comes the Israelite tradition
speaker: Narrator

text: that each year the young women of Israel go out for four days to commemorate the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ephraimite forces were called out, and they crossed over to Zaphon. They said to Jephthah, “Why did you go to fight the Ammonites without calling us to go with you? We’re going to burn down your house over your head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah answered, “I and my people were engaged in a great struggle with the Ammonites, and although I called, you didn’t save me out of their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I saw that you wouldn’t help, I took my life in my hands and crossed over to fight the Ammonites, and the Lord gave me the victory over them. Now why have you come up today to fight me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah then called together the men of Gilead and fought against Ephraim. The Gileadites struck them down because the Ephraimites had said, “You Gileadites are renegades from Ephraim and Manasseh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gileadites captured the fords of the Jordan leading to Ephraim, and whenever a survivor of Ephraim said, “Let me cross over,” the men of Gilead asked him, “Are you an Ephraimite?” If he replied, “No,”
speaker: Narrator

text: they said, “All right, say ‘Shibboleth.’” If he said, “Sibboleth,” because he could not pronounce the word correctly, they seized him and killed him at the fords of the Jordan. Forty-two thousand Ephraimites were killed at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah led Israel six years. Then Jephthah the Gileadite died and was buried in a town in Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him, Ibzan of Bethlehem led Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had thirty sons and thirty daughters. He gave his daughters away in marriage to those outside his clan, and for his sons he brought in thirty young women as wives from outside his clan. Ibzan led Israel seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ibzan died and was buried in Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him, Elon the Zebulunite led Israel ten years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elon died and was buried in Aijalon in the land of Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him, Abdon son of Hillel, from Pirathon, led Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had forty sons and thirty grandsons, who rode on seventy donkeys. He led Israel eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abdon son of Hillel died and was buried at Pirathon in Ephraim, in the hill country of the Amalekites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the Israelites did evil in the eyes of the Lord, so the Lord delivered them into the hands of the Philistines for forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: A certain man of Zorah, named Manoah, from the clan of the Danites, had a wife who was childless, unable to give birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord appeared to her and said, “You are barren and childless, but you are going to become pregnant and give birth to a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now see to it that you drink no wine or other fermented drink and that you do not eat anything unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will become pregnant and have a son whose head is never to be touched by a razor because the boy is to be a Nazirite, dedicated to God from the womb. He will take the lead in delivering Israel from the hands of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the woman went to her husband and told him, “A man of God came to me. He looked like an angel of God, very awesome. I didn’t ask him where he came from, and he didn’t tell me his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said to me, ‘You will become pregnant and have a son. Now then, drink no wine or other fermented drink and do not eat anything unclean, because the boy will be a Nazirite of God from the womb until the day of his death.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Manoah prayed to the Lord: “Pardon your servant, Lord. I beg you to let the man of God you sent to us come again to teach us how to bring up the boy who is to be born.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God heard Manoah, and the angel of God came again to the woman while she was out in the field; but her husband Manoah was not with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman hurried to tell her husband, “He’s here! The man who appeared to me the other day!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Manoah got up and followed his wife. When he came to the man, he said, “Are you the man who talked to my wife?”
“I am,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Manoah asked him, “When your words are fulfilled, what is to be the rule that governs the boy’s life and work?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord answered, “Your wife must do all that I have told her.
speaker: Narrator

text: She must not eat anything that comes from the grapevine, nor drink any wine or other fermented drink nor eat anything unclean. She must do everything I have commanded her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Manoah said to the angel of the Lord, “We would like you to stay until we prepare a young goat for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord replied, “Even though you detain me, I will not eat any of your food. But if you prepare a burnt offering, offer it to the Lord.” (Manoah did not realize that it was the angel of the Lord.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Manoah inquired of the angel of the Lord, “What is your name, so that we may honor you when your word comes true?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “Why do you ask my name? It is beyond understanding.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Manoah took a young goat, together with the grain offering, and sacrificed it on a rock to the Lord. And the Lord did an amazing thing while Manoah and his wife watched:
speaker: Narrator

text: As the flame blazed up from the altar toward heaven, the angel of the Lord ascended in the flame. Seeing this, Manoah and his wife fell with their faces to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the angel of the Lord did not show himself again to Manoah and his wife, Manoah realized that it was the angel of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “We are doomed to die!” he said to his wife. “We have seen God!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But his wife answered, “If the Lord had meant to kill us, he would not have accepted a burnt offering and grain offering from our hands, nor shown us all these things or now told us this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman gave birth to a boy and named him Samson. He grew and the Lord blessed him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Spirit of the Lord began to stir him while he was in Mahaneh Dan, between Zorah and Eshtaol.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson went down to Timnah and saw there a young Philistine woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he returned, he said to his father and mother, “I have seen a Philistine woman in Timnah; now get her for me as my wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
His father and mother replied, “Isn’t there an acceptable woman among your relatives or among all our people? Must you go to the uncircumcised Philistines to get a wife?”
But Samson said to his father, “Get her for me. She’s the right one for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (His parents did not know that this was from the Lord, who was seeking an occasion to confront the Philistines; for at that time they were ruling over Israel.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson went down to Timnah together with his father and mother. As they approached the vineyards of Timnah, suddenly a young lion came roaring toward him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Spirit of the Lord came powerfully upon him so that he tore the lion apart with his bare hands as he might have torn a young goat. But he told neither his father nor his mother what he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went down and talked with the woman, and he liked her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, when he went back to marry her, he turned aside to look at the lion’s carcass, and in it he saw a swarm of bees and some honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: He scooped out the honey with his hands and ate as he went along. When he rejoined his parents, he gave them some, and they too ate it. But he did not tell them that he had taken the honey from the lion’s carcass.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now his father went down to see the woman. And there Samson held a feast, as was customary for young men.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people saw him, they chose thirty men to be his companions.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let me tell you a riddle,” Samson said to them. “If you can give me the answer within the seven days of the feast, I will give you thirty linen garments and thirty sets of clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you can’t tell me the answer, you must give me thirty linen garments and thirty sets of clothes.”
“Tell us your riddle,” they said. “Let’s hear it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He replied,
“Out of the eater, something to eat;
    out of the strong, something sweet.”
For three days they could not give the answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fourth day, they said to Samson’s wife, “Coax your husband into explaining the riddle for us, or we will burn you and your father’s household to death. Did you invite us here to steal our property?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Samson’s wife threw herself on him, sobbing, “You hate me! You don’t really love me. You’ve given my people a riddle, but you haven’t told me the answer.”
“I haven’t even explained it to my father or mother,” he replied, “so why should I explain it to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She cried the whole seven days of the feast. So on the seventh day he finally told her, because she continued to press him. She in turn explained the riddle to her people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before sunset on the seventh day the men of the town said to him,
“What is sweeter than honey?
    What is stronger than a lion?”
Samson said to them,
“If you had not plowed with my heifer,
    you would not have solved my riddle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Spirit of the Lord came powerfully upon him. He went down to Ashkelon, struck down thirty of their men, stripped them of everything and gave their clothes to those who had explained the riddle. Burning with anger, he returned to his father’s home.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Samson’s wife was given to one of his companions who had attended him at the feast.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, at the time of wheat harvest, Samson took a young goat and went to visit his wife. He said, “I’m going to my wife’s room.” But her father would not let him go in.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I was so sure you hated her,” he said, “that I gave her to your companion. Isn’t her younger sister more attractive? Take her instead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to them, “This time I have a right to get even with the Philistines; I will really harm them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went out and caught three hundred foxes and tied them tail to tail in pairs. He then fastened a torch to every pair of tails,
speaker: Narrator

text: lit the torches and let the foxes loose in the standing grain of the Philistines. He burned up the shocks and standing grain, together with the vineyards and olive groves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Philistines asked, “Who did this?” they were told, “Samson, the Timnite’s son-in-law, because his wife was given to his companion.”
So the Philistines went up and burned her and her father to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to them, “Since you’ve acted like this, I swear that I won’t stop until I get my revenge on you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He attacked them viciously and slaughtered many of them. Then he went down and stayed in a cave in the rock of Etam.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines went up and camped in Judah, spreading out near Lehi.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people of Judah asked, “Why have you come to fight us?”
“We have come to take Samson prisoner,” they answered, “to do to him as he did to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then three thousand men from Judah went down to the cave in the rock of Etam and said to Samson, “Don’t you realize that the Philistines are rulers over us? What have you done to us?”
He answered, “I merely did to them what they did to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They said to him, “We’ve come to tie you up and hand you over to the Philistines.”
Samson said, “Swear to me that you won’t kill me yourselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Agreed,” they answered. “We will only tie you up and hand you over to them. We will not kill you.” So they bound him with two new ropes and led him up from the rock.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he approached Lehi, the Philistines came toward him shouting. The Spirit of the Lord came powerfully upon him. The ropes on his arms became like charred flax, and the bindings dropped from his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finding a fresh jawbone of a donkey, he grabbed it and struck down a thousand men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Samson said,
“With a donkey’s jawbone
    I have made donkeys of them.
With a donkey’s jawbone
    I have killed a thousand men.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he finished speaking, he threw away the jawbone; and the place was called Ramath Lehi.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because he was very thirsty, he cried out to the Lord, “You have given your servant this great victory. Must I now die of thirst and fall into the hands of the uncircumcised?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God opened up the hollow place in Lehi, and water came out of it. When Samson drank, his strength returned and he revived. So the spring was called En Hakkore, and it is still there in Lehi.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson led Israel for twenty years in the days of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Samson went to Gaza, where he saw a prostitute. He went in to spend the night with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Gaza were told, “Samson is here!” So they surrounded the place and lay in wait for him all night at the city gate. They made no move during the night, saying, “At dawn we’ll kill him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Samson lay there only until the middle of the night. Then he got up and took hold of the doors of the city gate, together with the two posts, and tore them loose, bar and all. He lifted them to his shoulders and carried them to the top of the hill that faces Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, he fell in love with a woman in the Valley of Sorek whose name was Delilah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rulers of the Philistines went to her and said, “See if you can lure him into showing you the secret of his great strength and how we can overpower him so we may tie him up and subdue him. Each one of us will give you eleven hundred shekels of silver.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Delilah said to Samson, “Tell me the secret of your great strength and how you can be tied up and subdued.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson answered her, “If anyone ties me with seven fresh bowstrings that have not been dried, I’ll become as weak as any other man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the rulers of the Philistines brought her seven fresh bowstrings that had not been dried, and she tied him with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: With men hidden in the room, she called to him, “Samson, the Philistines are upon you!” But he snapped the bowstrings as easily as a piece of string snaps when it comes close to a flame. So the secret of his strength was not discovered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Delilah said to Samson, “You have made a fool of me; you lied to me. Come now, tell me how you can be tied.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “If anyone ties me securely with new ropes that have never been used, I’ll become as weak as any other man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Delilah took new ropes and tied him with them. Then, with men hidden in the room, she called to him, “Samson, the Philistines are upon you!” But he snapped the ropes off his arms as if they were threads.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Delilah then said to Samson, “All this time you have been making a fool of me and lying to me. Tell me how you can be tied.”
He replied, “If you weave the seven braids of my head into the fabric on the loom and tighten it with the pin, I’ll become as weak as any other man.” So while he was sleeping, Delilah took the seven braids of his head, wove them into the fabric
speaker: Narrator

text:
and tightened it with the pin.
Again she called to him, “Samson, the Philistines are upon you!” He awoke from his sleep and pulled up the pin and the loom, with the fabric.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she said to him, “How can you say, ‘I love you,’ when you won’t confide in me? This is the third time you have made a fool of me and haven’t told me the secret of your great strength.”
speaker: Narrator

text: With such nagging she prodded him day after day until he was sick to death of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he told her everything. “No razor has ever been used on my head,” he said, “because I have been a Nazirite dedicated to God from my mother’s womb. If my head were shaved, my strength would leave me, and I would become as weak as any other man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Delilah saw that he had told her everything, she sent word to the rulers of the Philistines, “Come back once more; he has told me everything.” So the rulers of the Philistines returned with the silver in their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: After putting him to sleep on her lap, she called for someone to shave off the seven braids of his hair, and so began to subdue him. And his strength left him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then she called, “Samson, the Philistines are upon you!”
He awoke from his sleep and thought, “I’ll go out as before and shake myself free.” But he did not know that the Lord had left him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Philistines seized him, gouged out his eyes and took him down to Gaza. Binding him with bronze shackles, they set him to grinding grain in the prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the hair on his head began to grow again after it had been shaved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rulers of the Philistines assembled to offer a great sacrifice to Dagon their god and to celebrate, saying, “Our god has delivered Samson, our enemy, into our hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the people saw him, they praised their god, saying,
“Our god has delivered our enemy
    into our hands,
the one who laid waste our land
    and multiplied our slain.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
While they were in high spirits, they shouted, “Bring out Samson to entertain us.” So they called Samson out of the prison, and he performed for them.
When they stood him among the pillars,
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to the servant who held his hand, “Put me where I can feel the pillars that support the temple, so that I may lean against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the temple was crowded with men and women; all the rulers of the Philistines were there, and on the roof were about three thousand men and women watching Samson perform.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samson prayed to the Lord, “Sovereign Lord, remember me. Please, God, strengthen me just once more, and let me with one blow get revenge on the Philistines for my two eyes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samson reached toward the two central pillars on which the temple stood. Bracing himself against them, his right hand on the one and his left hand on the other,
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said, “Let me die with the Philistines!” Then he pushed with all his might, and down came the temple on the rulers and all the people in it. Thus he killed many more when he died than while he lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his brothers and his father’s whole family went down to get him. They brought him back and buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol in the tomb of Manoah his father. He had led Israel twenty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a man named Micah from the hill country of Ephraim
speaker: Narrator

text:
said to his mother, “The eleven hundred shekels of silver that were taken from you and about which I heard you utter a curse—I have that silver with me; I took it.”
Then his mother said, “The Lord bless you, my son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he returned the eleven hundred shekels of silver to his mother, she said, “I solemnly consecrate my silver to the Lord for my son to make an image overlaid with silver. I will give it back to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So after he returned the silver to his mother, she took two hundred shekels of silver and gave them to a silversmith, who used them to make the idol. And it was put in Micah’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now this man Micah had a shrine, and he made an ephod and some household gods and installed one of his sons as his priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days Israel had no king; everyone did as they saw fit.
speaker: Narrator

text: A young Levite from Bethlehem in Judah, who had been living within the clan of Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: left that town in search of some other place to stay. On his way he came to Micah’s house in the hill country of Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Micah asked him, “Where are you from?”
“I’m a Levite from Bethlehem in Judah,” he said, “and I’m looking for a place to stay.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Micah said to him, “Live with me and be my father and priest, and I’ll give you ten shekels of silver a year, your clothes and your food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Levite agreed to live with him, and the young man became like one of his sons to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Micah installed the Levite, and the young man became his priest and lived in his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Micah said, “Now I know that the Lord will be good to me, since this Levite has become my priest.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
In those days Israel had no king.
And in those days the tribe of the Danites was seeking a place of their own where they might settle, because they had not yet come into an inheritance among the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the Danites sent five of their leading men from Zorah and Eshtaol to spy out the land and explore it. These men represented all the Danites. They told them, “Go, explore the land.”
So they entered the hill country of Ephraim and came to the house of Micah, where they spent the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they were near Micah’s house, they recognized the voice of the young Levite; so they turned in there and asked him, “Who brought you here? What are you doing in this place? Why are you here?”
